    Judging with Objective Functions

    Daniel Klotz

    03_judgment.Rmd

    This chapter presents a set of functions to organize and/or visualize a set of objective functions that ought to be evaluated over all basins. The objective functions can be provided as a list via .ofuns. The pre-set objective functions are (these are provided by the coscos package, see also: distance metrics):

    • Nash-Sutcliffe Efficency: of_nse
    • Kling-Gupta Efficency: of_kge
    • Percentage Bias: of_pbias
    • Pearson’s Correlation Coefficient: of_corr

    The function judge_compute applies the provided objective functions to all basins. The computation is done for the overall time-span and for the marked periods. On top of that two functions for summary plots are implemented: judge_rasterplot and judge_barplot. A notable quirk of both functions is that they return a list as output (whereby each entry or sub-entry of the list contains a ggplot2 figure). Two interactive tools for exploration are provided by the judge_explore and judge_explore2 functions. Finally, the judge function wraps for all other judge_ functions. The selection is done via the type argument (the variable is evaluated in a non-standard fashion, which implies, among other things, that the argument can be provided without it being a character). Here are some examples:

    library(magrittr)
library(coscos)
library(visCOS)
    ## Warning: replacing previous import 'lazyeval::is_formula' by
## 'purrr::is_formula' when loading 'visCOS'
    ## Warning: replacing previous import 'lazyeval::is_atomic' by
## 'purrr::is_atomic' when loading 'visCOS'
    ## Warning: replacing previous import 'magrittr::set_names' by
## 'purrr::set_names' when loading 'visCOS'
    ## Warning: replacing previous import 'dplyr::last' by 'xts::last' when
## loading 'visCOS'
    ## Warning: replacing previous import 'dplyr::first' by 'xts::first' when
## loading 'visCOS'
    ## Warning: replacing previous import 'purrr::set_names' by
## 'magrittr::set_names' when loading 'visCOS'
    library(pasta)

    Example 1. Evaluating the judge function without arguments executes judge_compute, which returns a data.frame with the objective functions for the entire time-series and the marked periods (of each basin):

    viscos_example( ) %>%
  judge(.) %>%
  print(.)
    ## # A tibble: 12 x 3
##    of             basin_1 basin_2
##  * <chr>            <dbl>   <dbl>
##  1 nse              0.518   0.801
##  2 kge              0.725   0.749
##  3 pbias            0.251 -12.5  
##  4 corr             0.818   0.911
##  5 corr_period.1    0.824   0.881
##  6 corr_period.2    0.858   0.939
##  7 kge_period.1     0.414   0.849
##  8 kge_period.2     0.842   0.682
##  9 nse_period.1     0.133   0.757
## 10 nse_period.2     0.710   0.817
## 11 pbias_period.1   8.82  - 8.61 
## 12 pbias_period.2  -6.86  -15.9

    Example 2. Plotting the computed objective functions as bar-plots:

    viscos_example() %>%
  judge(., barplot) %>%
  .[[1]] %>% # a list with the plots is returned; select first entry
  plot(.)

    Example 3. Using the judge_ functionality:

    viscos_example() %>%
  judge_barplot(.) %>%
  .[[1]] %>% # a list with the plots is returned; select one entry
  plot(.)

    Example 4. Plotting the results of main objective function with a raster:

    viscos_example() %>%
  judge(., "rasterplot") %>%
  .[[2]] %>%
  plot(.)

    Developed by Daniel Klotz.
